name: pyftpdlib
description: Very fast asynchronous FTP server library

classifiers: Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries :: Python Modules

repo_metadata.description: Extremely fast and scalable Python FTP server library

owner_record.name: Giampaolo Rodola
owner_record.description: Python enthusiast and core developer, author of psutil and pyftpdlib python libs

advisories.title: Improper Input Validation in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: FTPServer.py in pyftpdlib before 0.2.0 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service via a long command.

advisories.title: Directory Traversal in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: Python FTP server library provides a high-level portable interface to easily write very efficient, scalable and asynchronous FTP servers with Python. Multiple directory traversal vulnerabilities in FTPServer.py in pyftpdlib before 0.2.0 allow remote authenticated users to access arbitrary files and directories via a .. (dot dot) in a (1) LIST, (2) STOR, or (3) RETR command.

advisories.title: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition') in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: Race condition in the FTPHandler class in ftpserver.py in pyftpdlib before 0.5.2 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (daemon outage) by establishing and then immediately closing a TCP connection, leading to the getpeername function having an ENOTCONN error, a different vulnerability than CVE-2010-3494.

advisories.title: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: Race condition in the FTPHandler class in ftpserver.py in pyftpdlib before 0.5.2 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (daemon outage) by establishing and then immediately closing a TCP connection, leading to the accept function having an unexpected value of None for the address, or an ECONNABORTED, EAGAIN, or EWOULDBLOCK error, a related issue to CVE-2010-3492.

advisories.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: Memory leak in the on_dtp_close function in ftpserver.py in pyftpdlib before 0.5.2 allows remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service (memory consumption) by sending a QUIT command during a data transfer.

advisories.title: Improper input validation in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: The ftp_QUIT function in ftpserver.py in pyftpdlib before 0.5.0 allows remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service (file descriptor exhaustion and daemon outage) by sending a QUIT command during a disallowed data-transfer attempt.

advisories.title: Improper Authentication in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: FTPServer.py in pyftpdlib before 0.2.0 does not increment the attempted_logins count for a USER command that specifies an invalid username, which makes it easier for remote attackers to obtain access via a brute-force attack.

advisories.title: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition') in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: Race condition in the FTPHandler class in ftpserver.py in pyftpdlib before 0.5.1 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (daemon outage) by establishing and then immediately closing a TCP connection, leading to the accept function having an unexpected return value of None, a different vulnerability than CVE-2010-3494.

advisories.title: Improper privilege management in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: The ftp_PORT function in FTPServer.py in pyftpdlib before 0.2.0 does not prevent TCP connections to privileged ports if the destination IP address matches the source IP address of the connection from the FTP client, which might allow remote authenticated users to conduct FTP bounce attacks via crafted FTP data, as demonstrated by an FTP bounce attack against a NAT server, a related issue to CVE-1999-0017.

advisories.title: Directory traversal in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: Multiple directory traversal vulnerabilities in FTPServer.py in pyftpdlib before 0.3.0 allow remote authenticated users to access arbitrary files and directories via vectors involving a symlink in a pathname to a (1) CWD, (2) DELE, (3) STOR, or (4) RETR command.

advisories.title: pyftpdlib Use of Insufficiently Random Values of port selection on PASV command
advisories.description: pyftpdlib before 0.1.1 does not choose a random value for the port associated with the PASV command, which makes it easier for remote attackers to obtain potentially sensitive information about the number of in-progress data connections by reading the response to this command.

advisories.title: Improper Access Control in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: ftpserver.py in pyftpdlib before 0.5.2 does not require the l permission for the MLST command, which allows remote authenticated users to bypass intended access restrictions and list the root directory via an FTP session.

advisories.title: Improper Authentication in pyftpdlib
advisories.description: ftpserver.py in pyftpdlib before 0.5.0 does not delay its response after receiving an invalid login attempt, which makes it easier for remote attackers to obtain access via a brute-force attack.

advisories.title: pyftpdlib vulnerable to allocation of resources without limits
advisories.description: The ftp_STOU function in FTPServer.py in pyftpdlib before 0.2.0 does not limit the number of attempts to discover a unique filename, which might allow remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service via a STOU command.
